I have a few things I want to say out of the gate. Iâ€™m going to complain first. Okay. I have complaints about the 1961 version. I have complaints about the 2021 version. Vika Teicher:

I do. I actually had to fast forward through a couple of Mariaâ€™s songs.

Sima Belmar:

Okay, great. Weâ€™re in agreement there. Yes, we know that the original and this one are both based loosely-ish on Romeo and Juliet. Vika Teicher:

I canâ€™t comment. Itâ€™s been a very long time.

Sima Belmar:

Right. We will not be talking about Shakespeare here. Anita is everything in both films.

Vika Teicher:

Yeah.

Sima Belmar:

Iâ€™m excited for us to get to your family and the connections you have, the ways you think about the film as someone who identifies, at least in part, as Puerto Rican, and comes from a big Puerto Rican family. Vika Teicher:

I have no idea.

Sima Belmar:

Whatâ€™s that one? Heâ€™s like a trapped creature and they fall in love. What is it called? The shape of things. I donâ€™t even know. Doesnâ€™t matter. Iâ€™ll look it up and then Iâ€™ll link it, but he did this huge tweet about the cinematography and how much he loved it in the 2021 West Side Story. He just went on and on. Iâ€™m not concerned about Hollywood films being authentic representations of anything because thatâ€™s not the point, especially a musicalâ€“fantasy land. I donâ€™t like it when itâ€™s offensive, like when the original had a bunch of brownface and fake accents and stuff, but otherwise, when people are like, what kind of gang member would like chassÃ©, itâ€™s stupid, right?

Vika Teicher:

Yeah.

And I canâ€™t, I kind ofâ€¦

Vika Teicher:

Yeah.

Sima Belmar:

â€¦ canâ€™t get past it. The producer, the director, the choreographer, the screenwriter, Tony Kushner.

Vika Teicher:

Yeah, behind the scenes, not the people we see, but yeah.

Sima Belmar:

Yeah.

Vika Teicher:

The money and the power.

Sima Belmar:

The money.

Vika Teicher:

To me, you could ask the question, why is the money in power still with them?

Sima Belmar:

Right. Why didnâ€™t Spielberg say, â€œYou know what? I think there needs to be, what anniversary, 60th? I canâ€™t do math. Yeah, 60th anniversary West Side Story. Letâ€™s get Guillermo del Toro and letâ€™s find a choreographer whoâ€™s also, and a screenwriter. And the movie might have been worse. It might have completely sucked. Thatâ€™s not to say that only certain people can make certain movies good or bad, but if youâ€™re really trying to intervene in historical injustices around money and power, then how do you just repeat the exact same structure at the top? Weird.

Vika Teicher:

But itâ€™s still Spielberg even if he engages these people. Itâ€™s still Spielberg who gets to make the decision. Oh, itâ€™d be interesting to have these people, itâ€™s still someone at the top.

Sima Belmar:

Youâ€™re right.

Vika Teicher:

So thereâ€™s a bigger question there.

Sima Belmar:

Maybe that shows that maybe there is not a Latinx person in sight who is interested in remaking West Side Story.

Vika Teicher:

Well, thatâ€™s a good question. I mean, I think, itâ€™s always going to go back to my mom.

Sima Belmar:

Good. Letâ€™s talk about your mom.

Vika Teicher:

B she would be like, ah, that happened in the past. She would just, no looking back. So maybe thereâ€™s something about that, a community that wants to be more forward focused.

Sima Belmar:

Thatâ€™s really interesting.

Vika Teicher:

I mean, if I were looking at the Puerto Rican community through the lens of my mom, that would be the answer. Obviously, sheâ€™s not representative. But if I look beyond my mom and just her sisters and brothers, my cousins, everybodyâ€™s forward thinking. The stories of reference of past are always funny stories about the family. Itâ€™s rarely a nostalgia for the culture, the Puerto Rican culture, or for the moment that they landed in New York City or anything like that.

Sima Belmar:

You mean when your family gathers, you donâ€™t get together and half the room is like, â€œI want to be in America,â€ the other half is like, â€œI want to go back to Puerto Rico!â€

Vika Teicher:

That would be so cool. If every time we got together, it was just a musicalâ€¦

Sima Belmar:

Yes.

Vika Teicher:

â€¦ and the choreography was fresh. It was musical.

Sima Belmar:

It kind of was a musical, I was just going to say.

Vika Teicher:

Thatâ€™s true. But it was the old songs from San Juan and there was dancing. So in a way, yeah, the gatherings were musical-like. I think theyâ€™re mostly just excited to have any positive-ish attention, that thereâ€™s a celebration of Puerto Rican culture and that theyâ€™re not like the criminals in the movie, but theyâ€™re alsoâ€“

Sima Belmar:

Theyâ€™re equally criminal.

Vika Teicher:

Yes. And also, celebrated and beautiful. I asked my uncle, Uncle Sammy, who you know, â€œWhat did you think by the way?â€ He was like, â€œI loved it. It was fun. It was fun. And it was well made.â€ Probably a sense of pride that Spielberg was behind. Probably, you know, theyâ€™re assimilationist. They want to align with the dominant culture. So thereâ€™s a dominant culture, someone with money and power, a white man wants to celebrate. Theyâ€™re not asking that extra layer that youâ€™re asking.

Sima Belmar:

And maybe Iâ€™m asking it just because Iâ€™m yet again, another annoying, white cultural critic.

Vika Teicher:

Or maybe theyâ€™re more in a survival still mode of just trying to not be hated here.

Sima Belmar:

Iâ€™m sharing a screen because this gets us to the main event of this conversation. This amazing article, itâ€™s 22 years old already, this article, itâ€™s called â€œFeeling Pretty: West Side Story and Puerto Rican Identity Discourses.â€ Itâ€™s by Frances Negron-Muntaner. It was published originally in Social Text in 2000. And I just want to read this opening. Bear with me, itâ€™s a little bit of a long quote.

â€œThere is no single American cultural product that haunts Puerto Rican identity discourses in the United States more intensely than the 1961 film, West Side Story, directed by Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins. Although neither the first nor the last American movie to portray Puerto Ricans as gang members (men) or as sassy and virginal (women), hardly any Puerto Rican cultural critic or screen actor can refrain from stating their very special relationship to West Side Story. Jennifer LÃ³pez, the highest paid Latina actress in Hollywood today,â€ 22 years ago, maybe thatâ€™s changed, â€œrecalls that her favorite movie was West Side Story. â€˜I saw it over and over. I never noticed that Natalie Wood wasnâ€™t really a Puerto Rican girl. I grew up always wanting to play Anita [Rita Morenoâ€™s Oscar-winning role], but as I got older, I wanted to be Maria. I went to dance classes every week.â€™â€

Iâ€™m pausing to say, I donâ€™t believe you. I think you always wanted to be Anita. Who wants to be Maria? I donâ€™t get it. Okay. Moving on.

â€œJournalist Blanca VÃ¡zquez, whose editorial work in the publication Centro was crucial in creating a space for critical discourse on Latinos and media, comments: â€˜And what did the â€œrealâ€ Puerto Rican, Anita, do in the film? She not only was another Latina â€œspitfire,â€ she also sang a song denigrating Puerto Rico and by implication being Puerto Ricanâ€¦I remember seeing it and being ashamed.â€™â€

Then, finally she [Negron-Muntaner] writes, â€œFor Island-born cultural critic Alberto Sandoval, the film became pivotal in his own identity formation: â€˜â€œAlberto, Iâ€™ve just met a guy named Alberto,â€ thatâ€™s Alberto singing about himself. Anyway, okay. â€œâ€™And how can I forget those who upon my arrival would start tapping flamenco steps and squealing, â€œI like to be in America?â€ As the years passed by I grew accustomed to their actions and reactions to my presence. I would smile and ignore the stereotype of Puerto Ricans that Hollywood promotes.â€™â€

So weâ€™ve got Jennifer LÃ³pez loving West Side Story and totally identifying with it and not worrying about any of the problematic aspects, at least when she was a girl. We have Blanca VÃ¡zquez being ashamed of the representation. And then we have Alberto Sandoval suffering. Sandoval is remembering people, after the movie came out, coming up and singing to him in his name and joking around and pretending to be the faux Puerto Ricans and how he just didnâ€™t worry about it. Negron-Muntaner in the next paragraph says, â€œOne of the ironies of the filmâ€™s centrality in Puerto Rican identity discourses, however, is the universal consensus by both critics and creators of West Side Story that the film is not, in any way, â€˜aboutâ€™ Puerto Rican culture, migration, or community life.â€ Then she just goes on to basically say it was made by a bunch of Jews. They were going to make it about Jews and Catholics. They changed their mind. Someone, Bernstein, Leonard Bernstein, I donâ€™t know, read an article about Puerto Rican gangs. They went to one Puerto Rican dance or something and they were like, â€œWe got it.â€ They made the movie as they are.

Then, her whole article just tries to parse where the identifications happen, how West Side Story fits in Puerto Rican identity discourses, conversations around what it means to be Puerto Rican at the time and up to the moment. Sixty years later, we have an article by Dr. Frances Negron-Muntaner. Itâ€™s called â€œWest Side Story: 60 Years Later-The Time For Us is Now.â€ It is published on the website Womenâ€™s Media Center and the first thing you see is Steven Spielbergâ€™s smiling face.

Vika Teicher:

The time for us is now.

Sima Belmar:

And heâ€™s like, â€œHey, now. Here I am.â€ Iâ€™m not going to read a lot of this, but I love her opening line, which is, â€œLike a zombie that repeatedly eludes death, West Side Story is coming back to a theater near you, this time as a new film.â€ So she talks about the fact that there would be no brownface and that Spielberg â€œhired â€˜realâ€™ Latino actors and voice coaches to ensure accurate accents, even from Puerto Ricans, who in Spielbergâ€™s words, â€œhave lived in New York too long to remember where they came from.â€

Vika Teicher:

Even to say â€œlived in New York for too long to remember where they came from,â€ they were probably born in New York. Itâ€™s just assuming that all Puerto Ricans have to have been born in Puerto Rico. I donâ€™t know, how old is Ariana DeBose?

Sima Belmar:

This is the woman who playsâ€¦

Vika Teicher:

Anita.

Sima Belmar:

â€¦ Anita in the remake. She was born in 1991. So sheâ€™s 10 years old. She was born in Wilmington, North Carolina. Sheâ€™s 31.

Vika Teicher:

I bet you, if you looked at, a huge percentage of the cast is not from Puerto Rico to remember where they came from. Theyâ€™re from North Carolina. Theyâ€™re assimilated. Theyâ€™re here. What does that mean to remember where they came from?

Sima Belmar:

What can we expect from, how old is Spielberg? Is he in his 70s? Itâ€™s like my 70s Jewish uncles would not really have anything great to say here. Negron-Muntaner is talking about how Spielberg thinks the movie can help with anti-immigration sentiment, but sheâ€™s got a big yet, â€œthe critical issue for Puerto Ricans may no longer be about the movie as a text but what its resurrection tells us about power,â€ which is what we were just talking about.

In this conversation, there is still no place for us.â€ And sheâ€™s quoting â€œSomewhere,â€ the song from the movie. Thatâ€™s so funny. The â€œAmericaâ€ musical parody. Okay. Anyway, folks, Iâ€™ll link it in the show notes that there is a YouTube video called â€œAmerica: A Musical Parodyâ€ that is funny.

So Vika, talk a little bit about your family. Talk a little bit about your upbringing and the reactions that you had to this film, thinking about it in relation to your familyâ€™s history.

Vika Teicher:

I imagine my fatherâ€™s family. They were Jewish immigrants, Holocaust survivors, five kids and my grandparents living in New York. Got there first, I believe. I imagine them as like The Jets. Theyâ€™re white and they learned English and they were educated already and they figured it out.

Sima Belmar:

Iâ€™m obsessed with that. Iâ€™m obsessed with thinking about your fatherâ€™s family as The Jets.

Vika Teicher:

I know. Itâ€™s like, what can I say, theyâ€™re The Jets! They took the bait of whiteness, like so many white immigrants. Then what came with that, and maybe this was an expression of the trauma of the Holocaust, was to find the brown people and jump on the board of like, not them. Those are the bad guys, the black, the brown, the Puerto Rican, not them.

So as 1961 and Rita Morenoâ€™s rocking it as her Anita, my fatherâ€™s getting kicked out of the house because heâ€™s supposed to be going to rabbinical school, but heâ€™s sneaking a secular education at night and going dancing. He meets my mom who just came over from Puerto Rico, and I imagine my mom and the ColÃ³ns as the sharks. They meet in a speech and debate class at City College and then they go out dancing.

Sima Belmar:

Your dad is Tony and your momâ€™s Maria? Iâ€™m like, what? I mean, it is eerily West Side Story-ish when you put it this way.

Vika Teicher:

Anyway, to make a long story short, he gets kicked out. He gets busted. He gets kicked out of the house for not being a good Orthodox Jew. My dad was born in Berlin in 1935 and three years later, they left and they were hiding in Belgium, in France. To keep these five kids and two adults alive, and then to cut them off.

Sima Belmar:

Like you said, more than cut them off, to literally perform a ritual of mourning.

Vika Teicher:

That was the death that happened to my dad. That was the tragic romantic death, the consequence. So he ended up with his Maria, but he lost his family. Thereâ€™s a little bit of a difference, but thatâ€™s where the knife went.

Sima Belmar:

Then, the ColÃ³n family was incredibly embracingâ€¦

Vika Teicher:

Yes.

Sima Belmar:

â€¦ of your dad.

Vika Teicher:

Thereâ€™s a major difference that they welcomed him with wide open arms. They honored the Jews. There was never talk of trying to convert him. They accepted that my mother converted to marry him. It was just never a problem. And he was white and he was lighter skinned than anyone in the ColÃ³nâ€¦ Letâ€™s not forget that. But you know, theyâ€™re The Sharks. Theyâ€™re living in the South Bronx. They came over to escape poverty. My mom is the oldest of 12 kids. They were living in a dirt poor street in Puerto Rico, five of them. I may get the count wrong. Six of them born in Puerto Rico and then the rest, the new generation, the segunda tanda born in New York.

Sima Belmar:

What year did your mom come? Do you remember?

Vika Teicher:

Mid-â€™50s. She had dreams. She came to the US because she wanted to go to medical school. She wanted to be a doctor. She had her eye on the education prize. She was an assimilationist in the sense that she didnâ€™t have the space, the time, the energy to hold onto her culture, to have a lot of nostalgia. I mean, she loved the gatherings. We would get together and have these big feasts and lots of music and dancing. She loved all that part of it, but there was very little talk about Puerto Rican culture outside of family gatherings. There was very little effort to instill some kind of cultural pride, to make sure I understood where I came from. She didnâ€™t have a space for the consciousness of Iâ€™m Puerto Rican. I think for her, it got in her way. Her accent got in her way. Her gender got in her way. She was trying to be a scientist. I think she just had lots of negative experiences that she didnâ€™t want to look back on.

My dad and family came over in 1950 and then meanwhile, my mom came over around 1952, â€™53. Nobody spoke English when they landed.

Sima Belmar:

She could have been the accent coach.

Vika Teicher:

I thought a lot about the â€œAmericaâ€ song. We could almost have the whole talk about the â€œAmericaâ€ song, the Anitas and the â€œAmericaâ€ song.

Sima Belmar:

Itâ€™s the best scene in both movies from my point of view. Itâ€™s the most extraordinary, fun choreography, even when itâ€™s weird faux flamenco that has nothing to do with Puerto Rican bomba or salsa or anything. Itâ€™s still fantastic. Then the street scene is so exuberant and bright. I mean, you canâ€™t not get swept up in it. Then everything else just pales.

Vika Teicher:

I saw the movie, the 1961 at some point, I canâ€™t remember when, but I went to the Broadway adaptation of 1981. So my first real exposure was a field trip in fourth or fifth grade from New Rochelle. From Westchester County, we got on a school bus and we all went to Broadway and we saw West Side Story. I saw Debbie Allen playing Anita.

By the way, Iâ€™ll just say one thing about it. Rita Moreno changed the line, the most controversial line is like, â€œthe island of diseasesâ€ and tropical diseases. She, I believe, did not say that line. That was supposed to be in the line and she didnâ€™t. She felt like that was too harsh and didnâ€™t ring true, but Debbie Allen, who was from Texas or something, not at all Puerto Rican, as far as I know, said that line proudly. Proudly, maybe thatâ€™s not the word, had no problems with the line, but because of that, because there was no need to protect culture or anything like that, her choreography and when she said that, she really expressed it, she really articulated that disgust in a way that was different from either of the Puerto Rican actresses. I thought that was interesting.

Sima Belmar:

Morenoâ€™s negativity just feels coded in a love too.

Vika Teicher:

If my mom were playing it, she wouldâ€™ve added the tropical diseases.

Sima Belmar:

Of course, because she was likeâ€¦

Vika Teicher:

Authentically saying it. I moved to New Rochelle from Upstate New York where I was the only Puerto Rican and the only Jewish girl for hundreds of miles. Then, we moved to New Rochelle and suddenly it was like such an incredible mix of kids. It was the first time I was going to school with Black kids.

When we came home, back on that bus, I remember, kids said to me, â€œHow was that for you? Youâ€™re Puerto Rican. How was that for you?â€ And I remember it was the first time I felt almost like a kinship. Like I got included somehow. Like I was part of the people of color for the first time. There was a connection made from seeing the Broadway play as a class that connected me to the kids of color that was interesting. When I think about what I remember from West Side Story, I remember that comment.

Sima Belmar:

Like Negron-Muntaner could have interviewed you for her articles because of that. The way a cultural artifact that was absolutely not grounded in any kind of real Puerto Rican-ness, although she does talk about, there are some historical references in the original, in 1961 film. There are some reality moments, but thatâ€™s something like that just by dint of the fact that it is being a representation, no matter how flawed, can lead to this kind of connection. I love that.

Vika Teicher:

Right. You also had, I mean, they were watching Debbie Allen play it. They were figuring out what Puerto Rican was at the same time I was. I was like, â€œI donâ€™t know.â€ I should have known. I should have had more of a response to seeing that show on Broadway. My parents were just like, Letâ€™s just be white people. It was the assimilationist way of survival.

I saw the new one. What I remember, now were like months later is the yellow dress, Ariana DeBose rocking the dress. I have to say the cinematography also lands. I see the whole thing the way she used the space. It was so sunny and colorful and integrating with the people. She was fantastic in it. I could watch it over and over again. Then I went back to see the 1961 and I thought sheâ€™s also fantastic in it. Itâ€™s just at nighttime and sheâ€™s in a purple dress and itâ€™s more subdued and itâ€™s a different mood.

I have to say one more thing about Debbie Allen, Broadway rendition is that they didnâ€™t have the men and the women. â€œAmericaâ€ was just the women. Some of them hated America and some of them hated Puerto Rico. There was like, they were rougher on each other in a sense. It didnâ€™t have the gender piece. But Debbie Allen, when she did the chicken, she had these articulations that I was really struck by. Sheâ€™s making fun of the chickens on the bus or whatever and she embodies a chicken for a moment. She had to make it much more dynamic. Canâ€™t have this cinematography. She just has the stage.

Sima Belmar:

Iâ€™ve never seen West Side Story live. When I was watching the footage of Debbie Allen, my reaction was just like, Oh my gosh, itâ€™s so hammy.

Vika Teicher:

Yeah. Itâ€™s hammy and itâ€™s entertaining and in many ways itâ€™s almost more realistic.

Sima Belmar:

Huh.

Vika Teicher:

That it was all women. Thatâ€™s where that kind of conversation wouldâ€™ve happened.

Sima Belmar:

So if we think about the physicality in the films, when I was re-watching the dance sequences of the â€™61 version, and then I was watching the â€™21 version, The Jets in the â€™61 version, the choreography is just fantastic. The metaphors are very clear about scanning territory. To me, like a chassÃ© and a jazz leg makes perfect sense in the street because itâ€™s like, this is our area in the way that they moved through spaces with each other. And the reason why it is powerful as a representation, not of Puerto Rican-ness, per se, but of power, letâ€™s put it that way, to me, the Anita character in both roles, particularly when dancing is an expression of powerâ€¦

Vika Teicher:

Yes.

Sima Belmar:

â€¦ in every way, both in the context of the scene and in the effect on the viewer. If the actor is actually Latinx or even coded as Latinx, then that power gets transferred there. It gets connected. There is power. I feel one canâ€™t underestimate that and that because of the embodiment of it.

Vika Teicher:

Right.

Sima Belmar:

Itâ€™s embodied power. It is scene stealing. It is movie stealing. So no matter who actually has the power, whoever the puppeteers are and their money, what remains in the cultural consciousness, is those two powerful Latinx women.

Vika Teicher:

Yes. I remember some similarities with the use of the skirts in Saturday Night Fever and in Grease, even though it wasnâ€™t a Latina, but it seemed like it. It was like an Italian in Grease, but the Latino couple in Saturday Night Fever, it was just this use of the skirt, of the frilly skirt. I thought I saw some connection there.

Sima Belmar:

Yes. Itâ€™s what Negron-Muntaner calls the spitfire representation. In Saturday Night Fever, which comes first in this lineage, thereâ€™s the Puerto Rican, they are actually Puerto Rican. Theyâ€™re called the Puerto Ricans over and over again and the DJ is Puerto Rican in real life and speaks in Spanish and does little stuff. Itâ€™s my favorite movie. I can go down the rabbit hole. But right, the woman is wearing red and sheâ€™s arching. Itâ€™s always about like these big back arches.

Vika Teicher:

Right.

Sima Belmar:

Ooh, which we could be really like throwing the head back and whipping the skirt around. Weâ€™re in an audio medium, but Iâ€™m moving my ribs around and the pelvis and all that stuff. Then, in Grease, Cha-Cha DiGregorio, who is the absolute spitfire, is supposed to be Italian-American, but she is fully coded as Puerto Rican or as Latina.

Vika Teicher:

Absolutely.

Sima Belmar:

Absolutely.

Vika Teicher:

Absolutely. Right.

Sima Belmar:

Same skirt thing.

Vika Teicher:
